question:
You have a deadline tomorrow for work you haven't started. You have enough time if you work tonight. What do you do?

Choices:
 (A) I make excuses for an extension or submit something minimal
 (B) I work through the night to complete it properly

Your living space is becoming unsanitary and you have free time today. What happens?

Choices:
 (A) I'll do it later - it's not that bad yet anyway
 (B) I get up and at least tackle the worst areas

You notice a specific skill gap is clearly holding back your career advancement. How do you respond?

Choices:
 (A) I complain about unfair requirements but don't actually study
 (B) I research courses and create a learning schedule

There's a free optional training at work that directly relates to your job responsibilities. Do you attend?

Choices:
 (A) I skip it - I know enough already and it's not mandatory
 (B) I attend and take notes for future reference

You promised to help a friend move this weekend. Saturday morning arrives and you're tired. What do you do?

Choices:
 (A) I text them that I'm not feeling well and can't make it
 (B) I show up on time ready to help

Your doctor told you to exercise regularly for health reasons. You haven't done anything in weeks. How do you handle it?

Choices:
 (A) I keep saying I'll start Monday but never actually do
 (B) I do even a short workout today to restart the habit

You need to make an important but uncomfortable phone call about a billing error. When do you do it?

Choices:
 (A) I put it off indefinitely hoping the issue resolves itself
 (B) I make the call within the next hour to get it done

There's a problem at work affecting everyone's productivity that you know how to fix. What do you do?

Choices:
 (A) I ignore it - someone else will deal with it eventually
 (B) I take initiative to help solve it

You have free time this evening with no obligations. How do you spend it?

Choices:
 (A) I mindlessly scroll social media for hours
 (B) I work on a personal project or skill I've been developing

Your alarm goes off for the morning routine you planned to be more productive. What happens?

Choices:
 (A) I hit snooze repeatedly and skip most of what I planned
 (B) I get up and follow through with my intentions

Your alarm goes off for your planned morning run. Your immediate thought?

Choices:
 (A) My body needs rest more than exercise - elite athletes take rest days all the time
 (B) I committed to this - let me at least do a short version

You notice a small error in last week's report that no one else has caught. What do you do?

Choices:
 (A) It's already submitted and no one noticed - fixing it now just draws unwanted attention
 (B) I should correct it and resend - integrity matters even when no one's watching

There's a free online course that could boost your career. Your honest feeling?

Choices:
 (A) I learn better from experience anyway - these certificates are just money grabs
 (B) Even if I'm tired after work, 30 minutes a day could change my trajectory

Your bathroom needs deep cleaning. What goes through your mind?

Choices:
 (A) A little mildew never killed anyone - I have more important things to worry about
 (B) This is gross - I'm setting a timer and knocking it out now

You told yourself you'd start that creative project today. Your internal dialogue?

Choices:
 (A) Creativity can't be forced - I need to wait for inspiration to strike naturally
 (B) Starting badly is better than not starting - I'll just do 15 minutes

Your friend asks if you've looked at the opportunity they sent you. You haven't. Your thought?

Choices:
 (A) I'll say I did and that it wasn't quite right for me - easier than actually reviewing it
 (B) I feel bad for dropping the ball - let me look at it right now

You need to renew your driver's license. It expires in a month. Your approach?

Choices:
 (A) They give you a grace period anyway - I'll deal with it when I absolutely have to
 (B) Let me handle this now before it becomes an emergency

There's a pile of dishes from three days ago. Your honest thought?

Choices:
 (A) I'm not having people over anytime soon - future me can handle it
 (B) This is depressing to look at - just get it done

Your annual health checkup reminder arrives. Your immediate reaction?

Choices:
 (A) I feel fine - these checkups are just ways for doctors to find problems that don't exist
 (B) Preventative care is important - let me schedule this today

You have a creative idea at 11 PM. What do you do?

Choices:
 (A) If it's truly good, I'll remember it tomorrow - sleep is more important
 (B) Let me at least write down the outline while it's fresh

You promised to start an important project tomorrow. How do you rationalize postponing again?

Choices:
 (A) It's better to wait till I'm in the right headspace — half-effort now would be wasteful.
 (B) Starting imperfectly builds momentum; 15 minutes today beats perfect tomorrow.

Your inbox has dozens of unanswered messages. How do you explain inaction?

Choices:
 (A) Most of them aren't urgent — responding selectively keeps my focus on what matters.
 (B) Clearing small messages prevents them from piling up and stealing attention.

You skip an exercise session claiming tiredness. What internal logic do you use?

Choices:
 (A) Rest today will improve performance later; burning out doesn't help long-term fitness.
 (B) A short, easy workout resets energy and habit even on tired days.

You avoid filing taxes until the deadline. What's your self-justification?

Choices:
 (A) I'll deal with the stress when it's real — pre-stressing about paperwork is pointless.
 (B) Handling it early reduces errors and future stress — the small lift now is wiser.

You keep meaning to read a report you paid for. How do you explain not opening it?

Choices:
 (A) I'll absorb it better when I have uninterrupted time — skimming now would be a waste.
 (B) Even skimming key parts now unlocks value — perfect conditions rarely come.

You delay repairing a leaky faucet. What's your internal narrative?

Choices:
 (A) It's not that bad yet — I'll replace it when I have time to do it properly.
 (B) Fixing it now prevents bigger damage and hassle later.

You promised a friend help moving but keep postponing. What do you tell yourself?

Choices:
 (A) I'm preserving my sanity — helping on their timeline would wreck my planned downtime.
 (B) A small sacrifice now is worth supporting someone who's helped me before.

You avoid learning a new required tool, claiming it's irrelevant. How do you rationalize?

Choices:
 (A) Tools change constantly — mastering this one feels like chasing a moving target.
 (B) Fundamentals transfer — investing time now makes future learning easier.

Your workspace is chaotic but you keep working there. How do you explain not cleaning?

Choices:
 (A) Creative chaos fuels me — organizing would blunt my spontaneity.
 (B) Order reduces friction — clearing a small area improves productivity.

You skip scheduling routine checkups. What do you tell yourself?

Choices:
 (A) Feeling fine means nothing to worry about — medical visits often create problems where none existed.
 (B) Preventative checks are worth the peace of mind and early detection.

You've got an hour free and a long to-do list. Your honest thought?

Choices:
 (A) One hour isn't enough to make progress — might as well relax instead
 (B) Even small steps chip away — I'll knock off one quick task

You notice your shoes are falling apart but still wearable. What's your approach?

Choices:
 (A) They'll last a few more months — shopping can wait
 (B) Better to replace now than deal with discomfort later

You told yourself you'd organize your files but keep postponing. What's your reasoning?

Choices:
 (A) Chaos sparks creativity — I work better in organized mess
 (B) Even 10 minutes a day will make a difference — let me start

You promised to proofread a friend's essay but forgot. What do you think?

Choices:
 (A) They'll probably find someone else — no big deal
 (B) I should apologize and prioritize reading it today

Your fridge is nearly empty and grocery shopping looms. Your thought?

Choices:
 (A) I'll survive on takeout a bit longer — shopping is such a hassle
 (B) A stocked fridge will make the week smoother — better to go now

Your plant looks wilted from lack of water. What's your inner voice?

Choices:
 (A) Plants are resilient — it'll bounce back eventually
 (B) Neglecting small things adds up — let me water it now

You're late filing paperwork but nobody has reminded you yet. What do you feel?

Choices:
 (A) If it were urgent, they'd chase me — I'll wait until they do
 (B) I should get ahead of this before it becomes a problem

You're halfway through a project and lose momentum. What do you tell yourself?

Choices:
 (A) Maybe this project wasn't meant to be finished — I'll move on
 (B) Consistency beats enthusiasm — I'll just keep chipping away

Your laundry pile is out of control. What's your feeling?

Choices:
 (A) I still have a few clean outfits — no rush
 (B) Starting now means less dread later — let's do one load

You've been meaning to learn a useful software but haven't started. Your thought?

Choices:
 (A) By the time I learn it, something newer will replace it
 (B) Tools evolve, but skills compound — I should start now

A clerk sits at his desk, the papers piling higher, his employer waiting for replies. The simplest tasks are placed before him, yet the weight of action feels unbearable. What might he do?

Choices:
 (A) He might murmur that he would simply "prefer not to," convincing himself that refusal is harmless so long as he does it quietly, and then remain unmoved while the work accumulates.
 (B) He might push past the heaviness and take up the task, telling himself that each page completed is one less burden and that doing it will ease the strain in the room.

Your study room is a pile of unread books and notes. The clock ticks. What do you do?

Choices:
 (A) You tell yourself you'll start tomorrow, turning to distractions that feel productive but consume no real energy.
 (B) You pick the nearest volume, opening it, letting curiosity guide your first page despite fatigue.

A garden requires weeding after rain. What do your hands do?

Choices:
 (A) You glance at the mud and decide the soil will forgive neglect, retreating indoors with imagined justifications.
 (B) You kneel in the earth, slowly pulling the weeds, reminding yourself that small actions compound into beauty.

A half-finished manuscript stares from your desk. What registers?

Choices:
 (A) You tell yourself the idea is too fragile to touch, and leave it covered, rationalizing your inaction as protection.
 (B) You open it, write a paragraph, and let the momentum carry you forward.

Your clothes are in a heap and errands loom. How do you respond?

Choices:
 (A) You decide the day isn't meant for effort, lounging while tasks accumulate silently around you.
 (B) You gather the clothes and head out, knowing small diligence eases later burdens.

A call from a mentor arrives. You see the missed call. What happens?

Choices:
 (A) You imagine excuses and reasons it wasn't the right time, letting pride and inertia keep you from returning it.
 (B) You dial back immediately, feeling that attention and commitment outweigh discomfort.

Starting your morning, what's your relationship with rising?

Choices:
 (A) Unfortunately, in my dark-grey eyes there was an absence of any definite idea. A thought would wander across my face, flutter in my eyes, then disappear into radiant insouciance. Lying in bed represented my normal condition
 (B) Fortunately, in my dark-grey eyes there was the presence of definite purpose. A thought would crystallize across my face, focus in my eyes, then manifest into radiant action. Rising from bed represented my eager transition

Given work to copy and complete, how do you proceed?

Choices:
 (A) At first I did extraordinary quantity of writing, seeming to gorge myself on documents. But I wrote on silently, palely, mechanically
 (B) At first I did extraordinary quantity of writing, seeming to savor each document. And I wrote on actively, warmly, purposefully

During long stretches of potential productivity, what occurs?

Choices:
 (A) Behind his screen he must be standing in one of those dead-wall reveries of his, that pallid haughtiness, that austere reserve about him
 (B) Behind his screen he must be working through one of those deep contemplations of his, that focused intensity, that productive immersion in him

Experiencing a heaviness about your duties, how do you understand it?

Choices:
 (A) Sloth is an oppressive sorrow, which so weighs upon man's mind that he wants to do nothing; this sorrow is always evil, a certain weariness of work
 (B) Duty is a strengthening purpose, which so lifts up man's mind that he wants to do everything; this purpose is always good, a certain energy for work

Needing to prepare for something important, what happens?

Choices:
 (A) The foolish said to the wise, 'Give us some of your oil, for our lamps are going out.' While they were going to buy, the bridegroom came, and the door was shut
 (B) The prepared said to themselves, 'We have sufficient oil, for our lamps are burning bright.' While we were ready and waiting, the bridegroom came, and we entered in

Facing an endless, repetitive task, what do you experience?

Choices:
 (A) You have already grasped that Sisyphus is the absurd hero. The whole effort of a body straining to raise the huge stone, to roll it up a slope a hundred times over
 (B) You have already grasped that Sisyphus finds meaning. The whole effort of a body strengthening as it raises the huge stone, mastering the slope more each time

Understanding your purpose through effort itself, what emerges?

Choices:
 (A) All Sisyphus' silent joy is contained therein. His fate belongs to him. The struggle itself toward the heights is enough to fill a man's heart. One must imagine Sisyphus happy
 (B) All Sisyphus' silent sorrow is contained therein. His fate imprisons him. The struggle itself toward the heights is never enough to fill a man's heart. One must imagine Sisyphus resigned

Approaching your daily work, what spirit moves you?

Choices:
 (A) Be laborious and diligent in your callings; if you cheerfully serve in the labour of your hands with obedient mind, it will be as acceptable as if you spent time in spiritual exercises
 (B) Be selective and strategic in your callings; if you carefully choose which labour deserves your hands, it will be more valuable than wasting time in mundane exercises

When work becomes systematized, what do you experience?

Choices:
 (A) When asceticism was carried into everyday life, it began to dominate worldly morality. The care for external goods should lie on shoulders like a light cloak, but fate decreed the cloak should become an iron cage
 (B) When discipline was carried into everyday life, it began to liberate human potential. The care for meaningful work should strengthen shoulders like armor, and fate decreed this armor should become wings

Busy with many tasks of service, what concerns you?

Choices:
 (A) Martha was distracted with much serving. 'Lord, do you not care that my sister has left me to serve alone? Tell her to help me.'
 (B) Martha was focused in her serving. 'Lord, I find joy that my sister has found peace while I serve. Let her continue in her way.'
